review_blob: Wonderfully balanced IPA with a punch in the face hop profile.  I have had this now in both a draft at the brewpub and in a take-away 4 pack of bottles.  Great stuff.

This is pretty much a classic example of a California inspired IPA.  it is bold but not overwhelming.  The fact that it is a real ale and has the yeast sediment to prove it wins favor in my book.  It is a beautifully hazy shade of medium golden amber.  The head is bright white but dissolves quickly, yet laces well.  Im a fan.
Stubbies intrigue me.  This is super sweet and overly malty.  It needs some serious hop additions or some additional character.  Its just odd.  Not one of my favs.

Lovely golden pour with a massive whipped cream white head.  The fermentation is clearly the focus here as is true to style.  The malt and hop characters are background necessities but the carbonation and estery qualities are what really matter here.  Its not as bright or zesty as I have come to expect from the standard Belgian Strong/Golden ale, thus the lower palate and taste scores.  I would buy this again.

poured from a 750mL bottle.  big white frothy head that dissipated quickly but left a nice lace.  nose is wonderfully sweet and earthy.  if i didnt know better i would catch some Brett or wild character.  sediment laden but wonderfully rich honey color.  taste is bland however.  not much going on here.  overall, a solid, easily drinkable belgian blonde at cheap at $7.99 for a 750mL bottle.

Thanks for leaving this one at our house on New Years Eve.  Pours an awesome jet black color with a very cool espresso head.  Chocolate and Coffee esters hit you right away.  The flavor is robust and complex but the coffee/mocha character is the most lingering.  Love it.
beer_name: Thirsty Dog Siberian Night Imperial Stout

review_blob: Love this New York take on a twisty Belgian style.  The balance between yeast, malt and hops makes this one a winner.  Eminently drinkable, the Super Bowl was palatable as a result.
A more grassy and earthy pils than I have come to like.  Pours exactly how a pils should and laces well too.

On cask @ special sour beer tasting via Buckeye Beer Engine in Lakewood, Ohio.  For a lover of all things Jolly, this is magic in a glass.  It has all the roasty notes of the Noel and all the amazing zing of the Roja.  The Madrugada seems to make up the body of the beer.  On cask the natural fermentation adds wonderfully to the experience.  The best part is tasting it bit by bit as it warms and newer, bolder flavors emerge.  Pure heaven!  Thanks JP
Very dark, chestnutty brown color.  Smelled a little astringent but had a decent spice snap.  I would have hoped for a nice balanced hop profile to accompany the sweetness.  oh well

I have a slightly unfair affection for all things JP.  I detest Pumpkin beers and yet this was wonderfully proportioned for my taste, mostly because I couldnt detect any pumpkin.  The brett flavors and notes are prevalent as always, which I love.  They have done another magical thing with barley and bacteria.  Love em
beer_name: Jolly Pumpkin La Parcela No. 1 Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: On tap at one of the Karl Strauss brewpubs at CityWalk in Universal Studios.  Very aggressive hop profile and luxurious mouth feel.  Watch your tastebuds on this one, you may find everything else tasting like water.
beer_name: Karl Strauss Big Barrel Double IPA

review_blob: Nut brown color with a slightly off white, almost almond head.  good lacing and nice nutty aroma.  solid hop profile but not overpowering for the style.  very drinkable

eh ... nothing special here.  Buttery, banana, clove, and corriander dominates.  Not too sweet but not as much yeast character as I would hope a hefe to have.  What are you gonna do?  I probably wont go for this one again.

About the same color as the Dortmunder Gold and with a similar white head with clean, pronounced lacing.  Very malty and sweet, but balanced by a hoppiness that is a bit more muted than I would prefer, but probably appropriate for the style.
beer_name: Great Lakes Imperial Dortmunder - 20th Anniversary Beer

review_blob: Funk, Funk, and more Funk.  I love most Brett infected beers and this one is no exception.  More funk than the Hennepin but less than the Jolly Pumpkin family of beers.  The aroma is astounding and the punch in the face that the Brett lends is wonderful, if that is your thing.  If not, beware!

12 oz. bottles purchased at C.E. Reillys in New Harbor, Maine.  A Maine classic, Gearys is a nice pale ale that betters many of the east coast breweries.  I like the smooth texture and mild hoppiness.  I know that if my picky dad likes it, it has to be all right.

12 oz bottles purchased at C.E. Reillys in New Harbor, Maine.  Sharp bitterness, almost too sharp for the style.  Two in a row might be my maximum on this one.  I enjoyed the 6 pack and would buy it again.  I wonder if this on tap would be any easier going.
A very solid APA, without anything spectacular.  I could easily burn through a 6 of these on a hot, summer afternoon.  Very close to the real ale flavor and feeling that I have been looking for.

Same sample pour as Brigadier at the Beer Engine.  I concur with most of his observations however, I would comment on the low to almost non-existent carbonation.  The acidity/sourness of the lambic more than makes up for this in the mouthfeel.
Light pink pour with a bubbly effervescence.  Very enjoyable lambic but not as sour as some of the others by cantillion.
poopy white!  Roused yeast take away from the flavor and there is almost no discernible uniqueness which should be the halmark of a wit.
Pretty much the definition of the belgian wit.  Nothing says summer like a Hoegaarden while sitting in a beirgarden under the shade of a newly leafed tree.  yum
12 oz. bottle: Average light brown pour.  Seems like the added caramel color instead of caramel malts.  Nothing special.

Bottle. Pours a pale hue of orange with a pretty bright white head. Yeasty scents abound with a slight champagne grape scent towards the end. Banana flavors with slight nutmeg aftertaste. Sparking mouthfeel. This is an above average Belgian white. Summer is in this bottle.

Pours a very typical hazy yellow with a bright white head.  The nose is citrusy and carries some coriander and banana.  First taste is snappy but not too much so.  There is not an overwhelming belgian yeast punch which I tend to like.  I agree with dirt55 in that it leaves your palate quickly and leaves me craving more.

Draft at Hop Fest, Buckeye Beer Engine, Lakewood Ohio!  Very nice, light hop aroma that left me asking  "what was that?"  Cool, amber color and nice floral, but not very floral, nose.  A solid IPA without much to hang a hat on.

Cask, Castle Inn, Bradford-on-Avon ... This is the house ale at this idyllic Freehouse just outside Bath, England.  Nice dark brown color and average off white head.  Smells of floral single hop addition and simple malt.  A solid session style ale.
Cask, Castle Inn, Bradford-on-Avon ... average at best ... enjoyable as a session beer but nothing that really stands out.  Again, idyllic settings make things taste better.

Cask, Castle Inn, Bradford-on-Avon ... Reddish brown with a quickly dissipating head.  Nice bitter aroma and flavour.  I detected a wisp of something out of the ordinary, almost Brettanomyces like.  I liked it but I am unsure if it was supposed to be there?
Cask, Castle Inn, Bradford-on-Avon ... Average at best, however I enjoyed this in an idyllic setting at a small pub just outside Bath, England.  That probably helped make it taste better.
If you like a swift kick in the tastebuds this is your winner.  Not too malty, not too hoppy, but long on flavor and balance.  I did like it and I do have the sophistication to appreciate this!

750 mL bottle purchased at the local grocery.  Hazy,  slightly orange pour with a whipped cream head.  Lots of sediment, even early on in the pour.  Lots of horseblanket and a tad sour.  I imagine that the lactobaccillious working.  Highly enjoyable, would try again.

WOW!!!!  12 oz. Snifter Draft at Beer Engine in Lakewood, Ohio.  During a Bells special event they had this on draft.  This is a punch in the face and a hop-heads wet dream.  What else can I say!  One hell of a Imperial IPA!

20 oz. cask draft at Beer Engine in Lakewood, Ohio.  This is a quintessential IPA that measures up against just about any other one that I can think of.  Wonderful, creamy off white head that sticks around for about half the pint.  The floral bouquet is just classic and the flavor is perfectly balanced.  What a wonderful introduction to Bells if you havent tried on already!

Light orange pour with a weak white head.  The smell is very banana for me with some clove and bread.  Taste has a nice initial bite that screams classic wit but is mellowed out as it rests on the palate, making me thing hefe.  I very nice blend of styles.

Draft at "The Pub" in Rocky River, OH.  Easy drinkin IPA with moderate hop character.  You can taste and smell the Challenger and Cascade hops but it is a bit muted compared to other IPAs.  For a scot IPA its not bad.

Draft at the Hopleaf in Chicago.  Nice but short lasting white head.  Not as funky as I expected from a Saison.  The horseblanket I was expecting was more of a horse throw pillow.  I would drink this again in a heartbeat but dont expect something sour or overly earthy!
Cask pull at the Goose Island brewpub in Chicago.  Nice off white head with a reddish brown body.  Not too hoppy and a touch of roasty malt.  I would have this again.
beer_name: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale

review_blob: Draft at the Goose Island brewpub in Wrigleyville, IL.  Part of a sampler.  white head with dark brown body.  wonderful overall brew, not too sweet or dry.  would try again
Bone dry finish ... probably the result of the rye malt ... very good solid beer.  I would drink this quite often.

Wow ... draft at Goose Island brewery in Wrigleyville, Chicago ... virtually no head but  a very interesting synthetic pink grapefruit nose ... seriously, try it!  There is a nice alcohol warmth that accompanies the very hoppy flavor!
Draft at Hop Leaf in Chicago .. nice overall flavor ... not that special.  Cool special glass!!

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: eh ... so so, but I do like the punchy maltness of this one.  If you like the same idea but want more hops, try the Roxy instead.  Pleasant overall, but again, I expected more.
beer_name: Magic Hat Odd Notion - Dark Wheat Ale (Winter 07)

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: Could have been so much better ... lacked the acidic punch I would expect from a hefe,  even if they say that the lemongrass is the main note.  Kind of a bummer, expected much more.

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: Nice amber color with a off white head that dissipates quickly.  Interesting hop/apricot aroma that continues on to be present in the aftertaste.  Interesting balance, sometimes a little floral for my taste, but still quite good.

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: Nice red-amber color with lasting lacing on the glass.  Head dissipates fast but lingers as lace.  Wonderful balance between hop and malt.  Cant quite pick up the hop type, Centennial maybe ... Cascade?  Piny/Grassy character.  a la Celebration Ale with more malt.  A good winter warmer without the spice.

I love sour ... this isnt sour.  The microflora the label speaks of lend little funk and little sour.   I agree with ElGaucho56 about the cherry/chocolate flavors, less intense than the Bells Cherry Stout, as I would expect.  However, the odd balance between sour and sweet makes it hard for me to classify.  I expected more given the deScription on the label.
This is now one of my favorites.  Sour is wonderful!!!  Earthy, horsey nose with a jowl rattling sour.  About as good as it gets!
Nice pour, limited head.  Had a grassy, flowery aroma.  Just what I expected from a good IPA
